Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an NMR Spectrometer for Research and Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program, Professor Anindya Ghosh from University of Arkansas Little Rock and colleagues Tito Viswanathan, Jeffrey Gaffney, Brian Berry and Darin Jones will acquire a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer with broadband capabilities. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) synthesis of ligands and catalysts for green chemistry applications; (b) synthesis of molecules for medicinal purposes; (c) synthesis of conducting polymers for photovoltaics; (d) self-assembly of polymer tethered nanoparticles; (e) synthesis of new donor materials for organic photovoltaics; (f) plant metabolonics; (g) chemical characterization of carbonaceous aerosols and humic materials in precipitation; (h) synthesis of metal complexes as cytoprotectors; and (i) proteomics.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research at the University of Arkansas Little Rock and neighboring institutions such as the historically black colleges and universities (HBCU) University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff and Philander Smith College.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Until 2013, Department of Chemistry at UALR did not have access to a high-resolution NMR instrument, which negatively impacted the department and other departments which require NMR in several aspects. The instrument has served UALR well in the areas of both research and student training. The presence of a high-resolution 400 MHz NMR instrument on campus has increased research activities both within the department and across the university. With the help of this instrument, we have been able to provide better training to both the graduate and undergraduate students.

The NMR has drawn in more undergraduate students who are willing to conduct research, and these students have shown increased interest in attending graduate school in various parts of the country. For example, recently graduated students have joined graduate programs at Purdue, the University of Illinois – Urbana Champaign, Georgia Institute of Technology, etc.  In the last couple of years, we have found that increased number of undergraduate students have been accepted in various professional programs such as medical, pharmacy, veterinary, and dental schools. We believe the exposure of the students to advanced instrumentations including NMR may have played a role in this by contributing to better research opportunities leading to more interest and options for them in further education. Both the undergraduate and graduate students from the programs at UALR have gone on to work in national and state laboratories such as the National Center for Toxicological Research and the Arkansas State Crime Lab, as well as industry positions including the Bayer Corporation which may also be attributed to improved knowledge on NMR instrumentation and data analysis.

The instrument has been used to teach and train students of General Organic Chemistry I and II, Inorganic Chemistry II, and Analytical Chemistry laboratory courses during the 2013-2016 academic years, including students from UALR (about 400), University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff (about 40), and Philander Smith College (about 80) have used the instrument as part of their laboratory training and curriculum. The Department of Chemistry at UALR has graduated eleven Ph.D. students from 2013-2016 who have gained proficiency in using the instrument and have had hands on experience in instrument handling and data analysis.

The instrument has also been utilized for academic outreach activities, including conducting workshops for about 40 students and teachers of the UALRTeach program on NMR Spectroscopy who will eventually enter the teaching profession to train students particularly in the STEM areas. Demonstrations on the instrument handling as well as its scope and applications in scientific research were given to about 150 middle and high school students and their teachers from schools in the central Arkansas area. PI, Co-PIs, and senior personnel have hosted students from the UALR High School Research Program and different schools for science fair programs and the students have had the opportunity to learn about the instrument and benefit from it as well.

The instrument has resulted in an appreciable increase in the number of graduate students enrolling in both the Masters as well as the Ph.D. program in the Department of Chemistry at UALR, as it allows them to access an extremely useful characterization tool for research. The instrument is currently being used by about 20 graduate students on a daily basis and is the mainstay of the department when it comes to characterization of organic molecules. The instrument has also been a positive influence in attracting new Assistant Professors. Dr. Darin E. Jones, an Assistant Professor in the Department of Chemistry, who has been working on developing small organic molecules, has used the instrument to generate preliminary data to secure the first collaborative RO1 grant in the department from the NIH. 

PI, Co-PIs, senior personnel, and other users are currently engaged in various research activities which include catalysis and synthesis using renewable reagents, polymers and nanocomposite material synthesis for various applications ranging from renewable and clean energy to sensors, organic synthesis of biologically active molecules, metabolite detection, and environmental chemistry. Within a short period of time, we have published 11 peer-reviewed articles in high impact journals, including Scientific Reports by the PI, and the grant has been acknowledged. Currently, several articles either have been submitted or are under preparation, and for these, the NSF support has helped tremendously. Additionally, one patent has been issued to one of the Co-PIs and few more patents are still pending. Overall the extramural funding in the University has increased in the last couple of years and NMR played pivotal role in generating data for developing proposals. At UALR, the use of this NMR has helped the faculty to attract several million-dollar funding from extramural agencies such as NSF and NSF EPSCoR (Ghosh, Berry, and Biris,), NIH (Jones), Arkansas Science and Technology Authority Grant (Ghosh, Jones), NASA EPSCoR (Viswanathan, Berry), and DOD (Biris, Ghosh).
